Terms.name: Plié
Terms.definition: Usually refers to a bend of the knee(s)

Terms.name: Tendu
Terms.definition: Passing from flat to demi-pointe to point where only the toes are touching the floor

Terms.name: Dégagé
Terms.definition: The foot of the working leg sharply brushes through the floor through tendu pointed in the air

Terms.name: Rond de Jambe
Terms.definition: The extended leg with pointed toe remains on the ground to sweep around in a semi-circle

Terms.name: Frappé
Terms.definition: Frappés involve tapping the foot (flexed or pointed) at both cou-de-pied devant (or wrapped) and derrière before extending out.

Terms.name: Petit Battement
Terms.definition: A movement in which one leg is extended and lightly moved forward and backward from the ankle of the supporting leg

Terms.name: Développé
Terms.definition: A movement in which the leg is lifted to cou-de-pied or retiré and then fully extended outward, passing through attitude.

Terms.name: Fondu
Terms.definition: Working leg begins fondu with the foot at the ankle of the supporting leg (in plié), the working leg extends out through and straightens along with the supporting leg

Terms.name: Grand Battement
Terms.definition: Straight supporting leg while the working leg tendu and lifts into the air

Terms.name: Chaînés
Terms.definition: Two-step turn that is performed when both feet alternate back and forth to keep moving in a line or circle

Terms.name: Sauté
Terms.definition: Jumping from two feet and landing on two feet

Terms.name: Fouetté
Terms.definition: A dancer will raise their foot in a “whipped” motion as it moves past the supporting leg in the opposite direction.

Terms.name: Pirouette
Terms.definition: Pirouettes are done by turning on one leg, with the other off the ground and in usually a passé position

Terms.name: Attitude Turn
Terms.definition: Turn in attitude position

Terms.name: Piqué Tour
Terms.definition: Stepping on a straight foot (the prick) with the working leg in a back passe

Terms.name: Grand Pirouette
Terms.definition: Pirouette in a la second (usually 90 degrees)

Terms.name: Soubresaut
Terms.definition: A quick jump from two feet and lands on two feet in fifth positio

Terms.name: Changement
Terms.definition: A jump from fifth position with the feet, jumping and changing the foot position in the air so they land with the opposite foot in front

Terms.name: Échappé Sauté
Terms.definition: A jump usually from first or fifth position into second or fourth position

Terms.name: Pas de Chat
Terms.definition: Jump in the air where both legs go through pasé

Terms.name: Grand Jeté
Terms.definition: A long horizontal jump in a developé manner (bent legs)

Terms.name: Tour Jeté
Terms.definition: A high turning leap starting with battement and finishing in arabesque

Terms.name: Sur le cou-de-pied
Terms.translation: On the neck of the foot
Terms.definition: A position where the working foot is wrapped around the working leg's ankle.

Terms.name: Balancé
Terms.definition: The type of waltz step that is usually in three counts and has the motion of going 'down, up, down'.

Terms.name: Tombé Pas de Bourrée
Terms.definition: Very common preparatory step for pirouettes.

Terms.name: Bourrée
Terms.definition: Very common traveling step done en pointe in a tight 5th position. Bourrée accross the stage was made popularized by Myrta's famous entrance in Act III of Giselle.

Terms.name: Échappé
Terms.definition: This step is usually done en pointe from 5th to 2nd position and sometimes from 5th to 4th position.

Terms.name: Assemblé
Terms.definition: Executed from a degage in plie and both feet are brought together in 5th position in the air.

Terms.name: Entrechat
Terms.definition: When a dancer beats their legs in the air and land in the same 5th position they started off with.

Terms.name: Glissade
Terms.definition: An in-between step usually starting from 5th position.

Terms.name: Promenade
Terms.definition: A step done in the center when a dancer stays in arabesque or attitude and rotates 360 degrees.
